dt: {bc}to acquire or get possession of usually by industry, merit, or craft
{bc}to get by a natural development or process
{bc}to make an increase of (a specified amount)

dt.t: {wi}gained{/wi} three percent in the past month

dt: {bc}to cause to be obtained or given {bc}{sx|attract||}
{bc}to run fast by the amount of

dt.t: the clock {wi}gains{/wi} a minute a day

et: Middle English {it}gaynen{/it} "to prevail against," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}gaainer, gaaigner{/it} "to cultivate, till, secure (profit, advantage), capture, acquire, be victorious," going back to Old Low Franconian {it}*waiđanjan{/it}, of uncertain meaning and origin

The presumed Old Low Franconian verb {it}*waiđanjan{/it} has no exact counterpart in neighboring Germanic languages, and given the diverse meanings of the French verb, hypotheses that explain it are all somewhat tenuous. The base has traditionally been taken to be that of Old High German {it}weida{/it} "pasture," Old Saxon {it}weiđa{/it}, from which a verb meaning "to pasture" was derived, which then hypothetically developed the sense "to cultivate, till" and further derived senses. Alternatively, the verb could be linked to Old High German {it}weidenōn{/it} "to hunt," a derivative of {it}weida{/it} "hunt, quantity of game taken, catch" (corresponding to Old English {it}wāth{/it} "hunt, chase, wandering," Old Norse {it}veiðr{/it} "catch, haul of fish"). In Middle English both the noun and verb are presumed to have crossed with borrowings of Old Norse {it}gagn{/it} "advantage, victory." Early Modern English {it}gain{/it} has acquired senses directly from Middle French and French {it}gagner.{/it}
shortdef: to acquire or get possession of usually by industry, merit, or craft
to win in competition or conflict
